# Linting

Linting your code is a good practice. That’s why by default, you got some rules.

# JavaScript Linting

ESLint is a must have to enforce coding convention and to prevent some syntax errors. The default boilerplate provide you a particular ruleset eslint-config-i-am-meticulous which provide a nice standard when you work is ES2015+ and React.

That said, you might want less rules (or semicolons).

# Less strict JavaScript linting

To remove the default config, you can replace the eslintConfig in your package.json with the following eslint config :

{
  "eslintConfig": {
    "parser": "babel-eslint",
    "extends": "eslint:recommended",
    "ecmaFeatures": {
      "modules": true,
      "experimentalObjectRestSpread": true
    },
    "env": {
      "node": true,
      "browser": true,
      "es6": true
    }
  }
}

In this example, we used eslint:recommended, but feel free to use one of the many existing configs. Here are some “popular” configs:

  • https://github.com/feross/eslint-config-standard
  • https://github.com/feross/eslint-config-standard-react
  • https://github.com/sindresorhus/eslint-config-xo
  • https://github.com/sindresorhus/eslint-config-xo-react

If you switch to one of this configuration, you might get some linting errors. To fix that, simply use the following command:

$ ./node_modules/.bin/eslint --fix .

This will fix all the errors that ESLint or plugins can handle.

# No JavaScript linting ?

Please don’t do that. But if you really just want linting for syntax (at least, you should do that), you can remove from the config above the extends line.

# CSS Linting

stylelint is a must have to enforce coding convention and to prevent some syntax errors. The default boilerplate provide you a standard ruleset stylelint-config-standard which provide a nice standard when you work is modern CSS.

# No CSS linting ?

Please don’t do that.
